trans-unit.source: Work with a JavaScript backend mobile service
trans-unit.target: Work with a JavaScript backend mobile service

trans-unit.source: Provides examples on how to define, register, and use server scripts in Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Provides examples on how to define, register, and use server scripts in Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: This article provides detailed information about and examples of how to work with a JavaScript backend in Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: This article provides detailed information about and examples of how to work with a JavaScript backend in Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: In a JavaScript backend mobile service, you can define custom business logic as JavaScript code that's stored and executed on the server.
trans-unit.target: In a JavaScript backend mobile service, you can define custom business logic as JavaScript code that's stored and executed on the server.

trans-unit.source: This server script code is assigned to one of the following server functions:
trans-unit.target: This server script code is assigned to one of the following server functions:

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Scheduled jobs[job scheduler]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.target: <linkText>HTTP methods defined in a custom API[custom api anchor]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.target: The signature of the main function in the server script depends on the context of where the script is used.

trans-unit.target: You can also define common script code as nodes.js modules that are shared across scripts.

trans-unit.target: For descriptions of individual server script objects and functions, see [Mobile Services server script reference].

trans-unit.source: A table operation script is a server script that is registered to an operation on a table—insert, read, update, or delete (del).
trans-unit.target: A table operation script is a server script that is registered to an operation on a table—insert, read, update, or delete (del).

trans-unit.source: This section describes how to work with table operations in a JavaScript backend, which includes the following sections:
trans-unit.target: This section describes how to work with table operations in a JavaScript backend, which includes the following sections:

trans-unit.source: The name of the script must match the kind of operation for which it is registered.
trans-unit.target: The name of the script must match the kind of operation for which it is registered.

trans-unit.source: Only one script can be registered for a given table operation.
trans-unit.target: Only one script can be registered for a given table operation.

trans-unit.source: The script is executed every time that the given operation is invoked by a REST request—for example, when a POST request is received to insert an item into the table.
trans-unit.target: The script is executed every time that the given operation is invoked by a REST request—for example, when a POST request is received to insert an item into the table.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services does not preserve state between script executions.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services does not preserve state between script executions.

trans-unit.source: Because a new global context is created every time a script is run, any state variables that are defined in the script are reinitialized.
trans-unit.target: Because a new global context is created every time a script is run, any state variables that are defined in the script are reinitialized.

trans-unit.source: If you want to store state from one request to another, create a table in your mobile service, and then read and write the state to the table.
trans-unit.target: If you want to store state from one request to another, create a table in your mobile service, and then read and write the state to the table.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to: Access tables from scripts].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to: Access tables from scripts].

trans-unit.source: You write table operation scripts if you need to enforce customized business logic when the operation is executed.
trans-unit.target: You write table operation scripts if you need to enforce customized business logic when the operation is executed.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following script rejects insert operations where the string length of the text field is greater than ten characters:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following script rejects insert operations where the string length of the text field is greater than ten characters:

trans-unit.source: A table script function always takes three arguments.
trans-unit.target: A table script function always takes three arguments.

trans-unit.source: The first argument varies depending on the table operation.
trans-unit.target: The first argument varies depending on the table operation.

trans-unit.source: For inserts and updates, it is an item object, which is a JSON representation of the row being affected by the operation.
trans-unit.target: For inserts and updates, it is an item object, which is a JSON representation of the row being affected by the operation.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to access column values by name, for example, item.Owner, where Owner is one of the names in the JSON representation.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to access column values by name, for example, item.Owner, where Owner is one of the names in the JSON representation.

trans-unit.source: For a delete, it is the ID of the record to delete.
trans-unit.target: For a delete, it is the ID of the record to delete.

trans-unit.source: And for a read, it is a [query object] that specifies the rowset to return.
trans-unit.target: And for a read, it is a [query object] that specifies the rowset to return.

trans-unit.source: The second argument is always a <linkText>user object[user object]</linkText><title></title> that represents the user that submitted the request.
trans-unit.target: The second argument is always a <linkText>user object[user object]</linkText><title></title> that represents the user that submitted the request.

trans-unit.source: The third argument is always a <linkText>request object[request object]</linkText><title></title>, by which you can control execution of the requested operation and the response that's sent to the client.
trans-unit.target: The third argument is always a <linkText>request object[request object]</linkText><title></title>, by which you can control execution of the requested operation and the response that's sent to the client.

trans-unit.source: Here are the canonical main-function signatures for the table operations:
trans-unit.target: Here are the canonical main-function signatures for the table operations:

trans-unit.source: Insert[insert function]: function insert (item, user, request) { ... }
trans-unit.target: Insert[insert function]: function insert (item, user, request) { ... }

trans-unit.source: Update[update function]: function update (item, user, request) { ... }
trans-unit.target: Update[update function]: function update (item, user, request) { ... }

trans-unit.source: Delete[delete function]: function del (id, user, request) { ... }
trans-unit.target: Delete[delete function]: function del (id, user, request) { ... }

trans-unit.source: Read[read function]: function read (query, user, request) { ... }
trans-unit.target: Read[read function]: function read (query, user, request) { ... }

trans-unit.source: A function that's registered to the delete operation must be named del because delete is a reserved keyword in JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: A function that's registered to the delete operation must be named del because delete is a reserved keyword in JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: Every server script has a main function, and may have optional helper functions.
trans-unit.target: Every server script has a main function, and may have optional helper functions.

trans-unit.source: Even though a server script may have been been created for a specific table, it can also reference other tables in the same database.
trans-unit.target: Even though a server script may have been been created for a specific table, it can also reference other tables in the same database.

trans-unit.source: You can also define common functions as modules that can be shared across scripts.
trans-unit.target: You can also define common functions as modules that can be shared across scripts.

trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Source control and shared code[source control, shared code, and helper functions]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: A table operation script must call at least one of the following functions of the [request object] to make sure that the client receives a response.
trans-unit.target: A table operation script must call at least one of the following functions of the [request object] to make sure that the client receives a response.

trans-unit.source: execute function: The operation is completed as requested and the standard response is returned.
trans-unit.target: execute function: The operation is completed as requested and the standard response is returned.

trans-unit.source: respond function: A custom response is returned.
trans-unit.target: respond function: A custom response is returned.

trans-unit.source: When a script has a code path in which neither execute nor respond is invoked, the operation may become unresponsive.
trans-unit.target: When a script has a code path in which neither execute nor respond is invoked, the operation may become unresponsive.

trans-unit.target: In this example, the item is inserted into the database and the appropriate status code is returned to the user.

trans-unit.source: When the execute function is called, the item, query[query object], or id value that was passed as the first argument into the script function is used to perform the operation.
trans-unit.target: When the execute function is called, the item, query[query object], or id value that was passed as the first argument into the script function is used to perform the operation.

trans-unit.source: For an insert, update or query operation, you can modify the item or query before you call execute:
trans-unit.target: For an insert, update or query operation, you can modify the item or query before you call execute:

trans-unit.target: In a delete script, changing the value of the supplied userId variable does not affect which record gets deleted.

trans-unit.source: You can also use a script to implement validation logic that can override the default response behavior.
trans-unit.target: You can also use a script to implement validation logic that can override the default response behavior.

trans-unit.source: If validation fails, just call the respond function instead of the execute function and write the response to the client:
trans-unit.target: If validation fails, just call the respond function instead of the execute function and write the response to the client:

trans-unit.target: In this case, a database operation (insert) does not occur, and a response that has a 403 HTTP status code and a custom error message is returned to the client.

trans-unit.source: For more examples, see [Modify the response].
trans-unit.target: For more examples, see [Modify the response].

trans-unit.source: By default in a table operation, the execute function writes responses automatically.
trans-unit.target: By default in a table operation, the execute function writes responses automatically.

trans-unit.source: However, you can pass two optional parameters to the execute function that override its behavior on success and/or on error.
trans-unit.target: However, you can pass two optional parameters to the execute function that override its behavior on success and/or on error.

trans-unit.source: By passing in a success handler when you call execute, you can modify the results of a query before you write them to the response.
trans-unit.target: By passing in a success handler when you call execute, you can modify the results of a query before you write them to the response.

trans-unit.source: The following example calls execute({ success: function(results) { ... }) to perform additional work after data is read from the database but before the response is written:
trans-unit.target: The following example calls execute({ success: function(results) { ... }) to perform additional work after data is read from the database but before the response is written:

trans-unit.source: When you provide a success handler to the execute function, you must also call the respond function as part of the success handler so that the runtime knows that the script has completed and that a response can be written.
trans-unit.target: When you provide a success handler to the execute function, you must also call the respond function as part of the success handler so that the runtime knows that the script has completed and that a response can be written.

trans-unit.source: When you call respond without passing any arguments, Mobile Services generates the default response.
trans-unit.target: When you call respond without passing any arguments, Mobile Services generates the default response.

trans-unit.source: You can call respond without arguments to invoke the default response only after you first call the execute function.
trans-unit.target: You can call respond without arguments to invoke the default response only after you first call the execute function.

trans-unit.source: The execute function can fail if there is a loss of connectivity to the database, an invalid object, or an incorrect query.
trans-unit.target: The execute function can fail if there is a loss of connectivity to the database, an invalid object, or an incorrect query.

trans-unit.source: By default when an error occurs, server scripts log the error and write an error result to the response.
trans-unit.target: By default when an error occurs, server scripts log the error and write an error result to the response.

trans-unit.source: Because Mobile Services provides default error handling, you don't have to handle errors that may occur in the service.
trans-unit.target: Because Mobile Services provides default error handling, you don't have to handle errors that may occur in the service.

trans-unit.source: You can override the default error handling by implementing explicit error handling if you want a particular compensating action or when you want to use the global console object to write more detailed information to the log.
trans-unit.target: You can override the default error handling by implementing explicit error handling if you want a particular compensating action or when you want to use the global console object to write more detailed information to the log.

trans-unit.source: Do this by supplying an error handler to the execute function:
trans-unit.target: Do this by supplying an error handler to the execute function:

trans-unit.source: When you provide an error handler, Mobile Services returns an error result to the client when respond is called.
trans-unit.target: When you provide an error handler, Mobile Services returns an error result to the client when respond is called.

trans-unit.source: You can also provide both a success and an error handler if you wish.
trans-unit.target: You can also provide both a success and an error handler if you wish.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services supports unique custom string values for the table's id column.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services supports unique custom string values for the table's id column.

trans-unit.source: This allows applications to use custom values such as email addresses or user names for the ID.
trans-unit.target: This allows applications to use custom values such as email addresses or user names for the ID.

trans-unit.source: String IDs provide you with the following benefits:
trans-unit.target: String IDs provide you with the following benefits:

trans-unit.source: IDs are generated without making a round-trip to the database.
trans-unit.target: IDs are generated without making a round-trip to the database.

trans-unit.source: Records are easier to merge from different tables or databases.
trans-unit.target: Records are easier to merge from different tables or databases.

trans-unit.source: IDs values can integrate better with an application's logic.
trans-unit.target: IDs values can integrate better with an application's logic.

trans-unit.source: When a string ID value is not set on an inserted records, Mobile Services generates a unique value for the ID.
trans-unit.target: When a string ID value is not set on an inserted records, Mobile Services generates a unique value for the ID.

trans-unit.source: You can generate your own unique ID values in server scripts.
trans-unit.target: You can generate your own unique ID values in server scripts.

trans-unit.source: The script example below generates a custom GUID and assigns it to a new record's ID.
trans-unit.target: The script example below generates a custom GUID and assigns it to a new record's ID.

trans-unit.source: This is similar to the id value that Mobile Services would generate if you didn't pass in a value for a record's ID.
trans-unit.target: This is similar to the id value that Mobile Services would generate if you didn't pass in a value for a record's ID.

trans-unit.source: When an application provides a value for an ID, Mobile Services stores it as-is.
trans-unit.target: When an application provides a value for an ID, Mobile Services stores it as-is.

trans-unit.source: This includes leading or trailing white spaces.
trans-unit.target: This includes leading or trailing white spaces.

trans-unit.source: White space are not trimmed from value.
trans-unit.target: White space are not trimmed from value.

trans-unit.source: The value for the id must be unique and it must not include characters from the following sets:
trans-unit.target: The value for the id must be unique and it must not include characters from the following sets:

trans-unit.source: Control characters: [0x0000-0x001F] and [0x007F-0x009F].
trans-unit.target: Control characters: [0x0000-0x001F] and [0x007F-0x009F].

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [ASCII control codes C0 and C1](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datalinkescapecharacter#C1set).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [ASCII control codes C0 and C1](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datalinkescapecharacter#C1set).

trans-unit.source: Printable characters: "(0x0022), \+ (0x002B), / (0x002F), ? (0x003F), \\ (0x005C), ` (0x0060)
trans-unit.target: Printable characters: "(0x0022), \+ (0x002B), / (0x002F), ? (0x003F), \\ (0x005C), ` (0x0060)

trans-unit.target: You can also use integer IDs for your tables.

trans-unit.target: To use an integer ID, you must create your table with the mobile table create command using the --integerId option.

trans-unit.source: A custom API is an endpoint in your mobile service that is accessed by one or more of the standard HTTP methods: GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE.
trans-unit.target: A custom API is an endpoint in your mobile service that is accessed by one or more of the standard HTTP methods: GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE.

trans-unit.source: A separate function export can be defined for each HTTP method supported by the custom API, all in a single script file.
trans-unit.target: A separate function export can be defined for each HTTP method supported by the custom API, all in a single script file.

trans-unit.source: The registered script is invoked when a request to the custom API using the given method is received.
trans-unit.target: The registered script is invoked when a request to the custom API using the given method is received.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Custom API].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Custom API].

trans-unit.source: When custom API functions are called by the Mobile Services runtime, both a <linkText>request[request object]</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>response[response object]</linkText><title></title> object are supplied.
trans-unit.target: When custom API functions are called by the Mobile Services runtime, both a <linkText>request[request object]</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>response[response object]</linkText><title></title> object are supplied.

trans-unit.source: These objects expose the functionality of the [express.js library], which can be leveraged by your scripts.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services enables you to define server scripts that are executed either as jobs on a fixed schedule or on-demand from the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services enables you to define server scripts that are executed either as jobs on a fixed schedule or on-demand from the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Scheduled jobs are useful for performing periodic tasks such as cleaning-up table data and batch processing.
trans-unit.target: Scheduled jobs are useful for performing periodic tasks such as cleaning-up table data and batch processing.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Schedule jobs].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Schedule jobs].

trans-unit.source: Scripts that are registered to scheduled jobs have a main function with the same name as the scheduled job.
trans-unit.target: Scripts that are registered to scheduled jobs have a main function with the same name as the scheduled job.

trans-unit.source: Because a scheduled script is not invoked by an HTTP request, there is no context that can be passed by the server runtime and the function takes no parameters.
trans-unit.target: Because a scheduled script is not invoked by an HTTP request, there is no context that can be passed by the server runtime and the function takes no parameters.

trans-unit.source: Like other kinds of scripts, you can have subroutine functions and require shared modules.
trans-unit.target: Like other kinds of scripts, you can have subroutine functions and require shared modules.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Source control, shared code, and helper functions].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Source control, shared code, and helper functions].

trans-unit.source: A server script can be assigned to a job that's defined in the Mobile Services Scheduler.
trans-unit.target: A server script can be assigned to a job that's defined in the Mobile Services Scheduler.

trans-unit.source: These scripts belong to the job and are executed according to the job schedule.
trans-unit.target: These scripts belong to the job and are executed according to the job schedule.

trans-unit.source: (You can also use the [Management Portal] to run jobs on demand.)
trans-unit.target: (You can also use the [Management Portal] to run jobs on demand.)

trans-unit.source: A script that defines a scheduled job has no parameters because Mobile Services doesn't pass it any data; it's executed as a regular JavaScript function and doesn't interact with Mobile Services directly.
trans-unit.target: A script that defines a scheduled job has no parameters because Mobile Services doesn't pass it any data; it's executed as a regular JavaScript function and doesn't interact with Mobile Services directly.

trans-unit.target: You define scheduled jobs in one of the following ways:

trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal[management portal] in the Script tab in the scheduler:

trans-unit.target: <linkText>3</linkText>

trans-unit.target: For more information about how to do this, see [Schedule backend jobs in Mobile Services].

trans-unit.source: From the command prompt by using the Azure command line tool.
trans-unit.target: From the command prompt by using the Azure command line tool.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Using the command line tool].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Using the command line tool].

trans-unit.source: Because Mobile Services uses Node.js on the server, your scripts already have access to the built-in Node.js modules.
trans-unit.target: Because Mobile Services uses Node.js on the server, your scripts already have access to the built-in Node.js modules.

trans-unit.source: You can also use source control to define your own modules or add other Node.js modules to your service.
trans-unit.target: You can also use source control to define your own modules or add other Node.js modules to your service.

trans-unit.source: The following are just some of the more useful modules that can be leveraged in your scripts by using the global require function:
trans-unit.target: The following are just some of the more useful modules that can be leveraged in your scripts by using the global require function:

trans-unit.source: azure: Exposes the functionality of the Azure SDK for Node.js.
trans-unit.target: azure: Exposes the functionality of the Azure SDK for Node.js.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the [Azure SDK for Node.js].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the [Azure SDK for Node.js].

trans-unit.source: crypto: Provides crypto functionality of OpenSSL.
trans-unit.target: crypto: Provides crypto functionality of OpenSSL.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <linkText>Node.js documentation[crypto api]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <linkText>Node.js documentation[crypto api]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: path: Contains utilities for working with file paths.
trans-unit.target: path: Contains utilities for working with file paths.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <linkText>Node.js documentation[path api]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <linkText>Node.js documentation[path api]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: querystring: Contains utilities for working with query strings.
trans-unit.target: querystring: Contains utilities for working with query strings.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <linkText>Node.js documentation[querystring api]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <linkText>Node.js documentation[querystring api]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: request: Sends HTTP requests to external REST services, such as Twitter and Facebook.
trans-unit.target: request: Sends HTTP requests to external REST services, such as Twitter and Facebook.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Send HTTP request].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Send HTTP request].

trans-unit.source: sendgrid: Sends email by using the Sendgrid email service in Azure.
trans-unit.target: sendgrid: Sends email by using the Sendgrid email service in Azure.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Send email from Mobile Services with SendGrid].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Send email from Mobile Services with SendGrid].

trans-unit.source: url: Contains utilities to parse and resolve URLs.
trans-unit.target: url: Contains utilities to parse and resolve URLs.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <linkText>Node.js documentation[url api]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <linkText>Node.js documentation[url api]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: util: Contains various utilities, such as string formatting and object type checking.
trans-unit.target: util: Contains various utilities, such as string formatting and object type checking.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <linkText>Node.js documentation[util api]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <linkText>Node.js documentation[util api]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: zlib: Exposes compression functionality, such as gzip and deflate.
trans-unit.target: zlib: Exposes compression functionality, such as gzip and deflate.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <linkText>Node.js documentation[zlib api]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <linkText>Node.js documentation[zlib api]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services exposes a set of modules that scripts can load by using the global require function.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services exposes a set of modules that scripts can load by using the global require function.

trans-unit.source: For example, a script can require request to make HTTP requests:
trans-unit.target: For example, a script can require request to make HTTP requests:

trans-unit.source: You can use source control with the Node.js package manager (npm) to control which modules are available to your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: You can use source control with the Node.js package manager (npm) to control which modules are available to your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: There are two ways to do this:
trans-unit.target: There are two ways to do this:

trans-unit.source: For modules that are published to and installed by npm, use the package.json file to declare which packages you want to be installed by your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: For modules that are published to and installed by npm, use the package.json file to declare which packages you want to be installed by your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: In this way, your service always has access to the latest version of the required packages.
trans-unit.target: In this way, your service always has access to the latest version of the required packages.

trans-unit.source: The package.json file lives in the .\service directory.
trans-unit.target: The package.json file lives in the .\service directory.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Support for package.json in Azure Mobile Services].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Support for package.json in Azure Mobile Services].

trans-unit.source: For private or custom modules, you can use npm to manually install the module into the .\service\node_modules directory of your source control.
trans-unit.target: For private or custom modules, you can use npm to manually install the module into the .\service\node_modules directory of your source control.

trans-unit.source: For an example of how to manually upload a module, see [Leverage shared code and Node.js modules in your server scripts].
trans-unit.target: For an example of how to manually upload a module, see [Leverage shared code and Node.js modules in your server scripts].

trans-unit.source: When node_modules already exists in the directory hierarchy, NPM will create the \node-uuid subdirectory there instead of creating a new node_modules in the repository.
trans-unit.target: When node_modules already exists in the directory hierarchy, NPM will create the \node-uuid subdirectory there instead of creating a new node_modules in the repository.

trans-unit.source: In this case, just delete the existing node_modules directory.
trans-unit.target: In this case, just delete the existing node_modules directory.

trans-unit.source: After you commit the package.json file or custom modules to the repository for your mobile service, use require to reference the modules by name.
trans-unit.target: After you commit the package.json file or custom modules to the repository for your mobile service, use require to reference the modules by name.

trans-unit.source: Modules that you specify in package.json or upload to your mobile service are only used in your server script code.
trans-unit.target: Modules that you specify in package.json or upload to your mobile service are only used in your server script code.

trans-unit.source: These modules are not used by the Mobile Services runtime.
trans-unit.target: These modules are not used by the Mobile Services runtime.

trans-unit.source: In addition to requiring modules, individual server scripts can include helper functions.
trans-unit.target: In addition to requiring modules, individual server scripts can include helper functions.

trans-unit.source: These are functions that are separate from the main function, which can be used to factor code in the script.
trans-unit.target: These are functions that are separate from the main function, which can be used to factor code in the script.

trans-unit.target: In the following example, a table script is registered to the insert operation, which includes the helper function handleUnapprovedItem:

trans-unit.source: In a script, helper functions must be declared after the main function.
trans-unit.target: In a script, helper functions must be declared after the main function.

trans-unit.source: You must declare all variables in your script.
trans-unit.target: You must declare all variables in your script.

trans-unit.source: Undeclared variables cause an error.
trans-unit.target: Undeclared variables cause an error.

trans-unit.source: Helper functions can also be defined once and shared between server scripts.
trans-unit.target: Helper functions can also be defined once and shared between server scripts.

trans-unit.source: To share a function between scripts, functions must be exported and the script file must exist in the .\service\shared\ directory.
trans-unit.target: To share a function between scripts, functions must be exported and the script file must exist in the .\service\shared\ directory.

trans-unit.target: This is because shared scripts cannot access the global [tables object], and the [user object] only exists in the context of a request.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services enables you to securely store values as app settings, which can be accessed by your server scripts at runtime.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services enables you to securely store values as app settings, which can be accessed by your server scripts at runtime.

trans-unit.source: When you add data to the app settings of your mobile service, the name/value pairs are stored encrypted and you can access them in your server scripts without hard-coding them in the script file.
trans-unit.target: When you add data to the app settings of your mobile service, the name/value pairs are stored encrypted and you can access them in your server scripts without hard-coding them in the script file.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [App settings].

trans-unit.target: [How to: Access tables from scripts]

trans-unit.source: [Using Transact-SQL to access tables]
trans-unit.target: [Using Transact-SQL to access tables]

trans-unit.source: Many scenarios in Mobile Services require server scripts to access tables in the database.
trans-unit.target: Many scenarios in Mobile Services require server scripts to access tables in the database.

trans-unit.source: For example.
trans-unit.target: For example.

trans-unit.source: because Mobile Services does not preserve state between script executions, any data that needs to be persisted between script executions must be stored in tables.
trans-unit.target: because Mobile Services does not preserve state between script executions, any data that needs to be persisted between script executions must be stored in tables.

trans-unit.source: You might also want to examine entries in a permissions table or store audit data instead of just writing to the log, where data has a limited duration and cannot be accessed programmatically.
trans-unit.target: You might also want to examine entries in a permissions table or store audit data instead of just writing to the log, where data has a limited duration and cannot be accessed programmatically.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services has two ways of accessing tables, either by using a [table object] proxy or by composing Transact-SQL queries using the [mssql object].
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services has two ways of accessing tables, either by using a [table object] proxy or by composing Transact-SQL queries using the [mssql object].

trans-unit.source: The [table object] makes it easy to access table data from your sever script code, but the [mssql object] supports more complex data operations and provides the most flexibility.
trans-unit.target: The [table object] makes it easy to access table data from your sever script code, but the [mssql object] supports more complex data operations and provides the most flexibility.

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to access tables from your script is by using the [tables object].
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to access tables from your script is by using the [tables object].

trans-unit.source: The getTable function returns a [table object] instance that's a proxy for accessing the requested table.
trans-unit.target: The getTable function returns a [table object] instance that's a proxy for accessing the requested table.

trans-unit.source: You can then call functions on the proxy to access and change data.
trans-unit.target: You can then call functions on the proxy to access and change data.

trans-unit.source: Scripts registered to both table operations and scheduled jobs can access the [tables object] as a global object.
trans-unit.target: Scripts registered to both table operations and scheduled jobs can access the [tables object] as a global object.

trans-unit.target: This line of code gets a proxy for the TodoItems table from the global [tables object]:

trans-unit.source: Custom API scripts can access the [tables object] from the service property of the supplied [request object].
trans-unit.target: Custom API scripts can access the [tables object] from the service property of the supplied [request object].

trans-unit.source: This line of code gets [tables object] from the request:
trans-unit.target: This line of code gets [tables object] from the request:

trans-unit.source: Shared functions cannot access the tables object directly.
trans-unit.target: Shared functions cannot access the tables object directly.

trans-unit.source: In a shared function, you must pass the tables object to the function.
trans-unit.target: In a shared function, you must pass the tables object to the function.

trans-unit.source: Once you have a [table object], you can call one or more table operation functions: insert, update, delete or read.
trans-unit.target: Once you have a [table object], you can call one or more table operation functions: insert, update, delete or read.

trans-unit.source: If you use a for or while loop to directly insert a large number of items (1000, for example) into a table , you may encounter a SQL connection limit that causes some of the inserts to fail.
trans-unit.target: If you use a for or while loop to directly insert a large number of items (1000, for example) into a table , you may encounter a SQL connection limit that causes some of the inserts to fail.

trans-unit.source: Your request may never complete or it may return a HTTP 500 Internal Server Error.
trans-unit.target: Your request may never complete or it may return a HTTP 500 Internal Server Error.

trans-unit.source: To avoid this problem, you can insert the items in batches of 10 or so.
trans-unit.target: To avoid this problem, you can insert the items in batches of 10 or so.

trans-unit.source: After the first batch is inserted, submit the next batch, and so on.
trans-unit.target: After the first batch is inserted, submit the next batch, and so on.

trans-unit.source: By using the following script, you can set the size of a batch of records to insert in parallel.
trans-unit.target: By using the following script, you can set the size of a batch of records to insert in parallel.

trans-unit.source: We recomend that you keep the number of records small.
trans-unit.target: We recomend that you keep the number of records small.

trans-unit.source: The function insertItems calls itself recursively when an async insert batch has completed.
trans-unit.target: The function insertItems calls itself recursively when an async insert batch has completed.

trans-unit.source: The for loop at the end inserts one record at a time, and calls insertComplete on success and errorHandler on error.
trans-unit.target: The for loop at the end inserts one record at a time, and calls insertComplete on success and errorHandler on error.

trans-unit.source: insertComplete controls whether insertItems will be called recursively for the next batch, or whether the job is done and the script should exit.
trans-unit.target: insertComplete controls whether insertItems will be called recursively for the next batch, or whether the job is done and the script should exit.

trans-unit.source: The collections of data types on the client and in a Mobile Services database table are different.
trans-unit.target: The collections of data types on the client and in a Mobile Services database table are different.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes they map easily to one another, and other times they don't.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes they map easily to one another, and other times they don't.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services performs a number of type transformations in the mapping:
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services performs a number of type transformations in the mapping:

trans-unit.source: The client language-specific types are serialized into JSON.
trans-unit.target: The client language-specific types are serialized into JSON.

trans-unit.source: The JSON representation is translated into JavaScript before it appears in server scripts.
trans-unit.target: The JSON representation is translated into JavaScript before it appears in server scripts.

trans-unit.source: The JavaScript data types are converted to SQL database types when saved using the [tables object].
trans-unit.target: The JavaScript data types are converted to SQL database types when saved using the [tables object].

trans-unit.source: The transformation from client schema into JSON varies across platforms.
trans-unit.target: The transformation from client schema into JSON varies across platforms.

trans-unit.source: JSON.NET is used in Windows Store and Windows Phone clients.
trans-unit.target: JSON.NET is used in Windows Store and Windows Phone clients.

trans-unit.source: The Android client uses the gson library.
trans-unit.target: The Android client uses the gson library.

trans-unit.source: The iOS client uses the NSJSONSerialization class.
trans-unit.target: The iOS client uses the NSJSONSerialization class.

trans-unit.source: The default serialization behavior of each of these libraries is used, except that date objects are converted to JSON strings that contain the date that's encoded by using ISO 8601.
trans-unit.target: The default serialization behavior of each of these libraries is used, except that date objects are converted to JSON strings that contain the date that's encoded by using ISO 8601.

trans-unit.source: When you are writing server scripts that use [insert], [update], [read] or [delete] functions, you can access the JavaScript representation of your data.
trans-unit.target: When you are writing server scripts that use [insert], [update], [read] or [delete] functions, you can access the JavaScript representation of your data.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services uses the Node.js's deserialization function (<linkText>JSON.parse</linkText><title></title>) to transform JSON on the wire into JavaScript objects.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services uses the Node.js's deserialization function (<linkText>JSON.parse</linkText><title></title>) to transform JSON on the wire into JavaScript objects.

trans-unit.source: However Mobile Services does a transformation to extract Date objects from ISO 8601 strings.
trans-unit.target: However Mobile Services does a transformation to extract Date objects from ISO 8601 strings.

trans-unit.source: When you use the [tables object] or the [mssql object], or just let your table scripts execute, the deserialized JavaScript objects are inserted into your SQL database.
trans-unit.target: When you use the [tables object] or the [mssql object], or just let your table scripts execute, the deserialized JavaScript objects are inserted into your SQL database.

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to work table data from server scripts is by using a [table object] proxy.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to work table data from server scripts is by using a [table object] proxy.

trans-unit.source: However, there are more advanced scenarios that are not supported by the [table object], such as as join queries and other complex queries and invoking stored procedures.
trans-unit.target: However, there are more advanced scenarios that are not supported by the [table object], such as as join queries and other complex queries and invoking stored procedures.

trans-unit.source: In these cases, you must execute Transact-SQL statements directly against the relational table by using the [mssql object].
trans-unit.target: In these cases, you must execute Transact-SQL statements directly against the relational table by using the [mssql object].

trans-unit.source: This object provides the following functions:
trans-unit.target: This object provides the following functions:

trans-unit.source: query: executes a query, specified by a TSQL string; the results are returned to the success callback on the options object.
trans-unit.target: query: executes a query, specified by a TSQL string; the results are returned to the success callback on the options object.

trans-unit.source: The query can include parameters if the params parameter is present.
trans-unit.target: The query can include parameters if the params parameter is present.

trans-unit.source: queryRaw: like query except that the result set returned from the query is in a "raw" format (see example below).
trans-unit.target: queryRaw: like query except that the result set returned from the query is in a "raw" format (see example below).

trans-unit.source: open: used to get a connection to your Mobile Services database, and you can then use the connection object to invoke database operations such as transactions.
trans-unit.target: open: used to get a connection to your Mobile Services database, and you can then use the connection object to invoke database operations such as transactions.

trans-unit.source: These methods give you increasingly more low-level control over the query processing.
trans-unit.target: These methods give you increasingly more low-level control over the query processing.

trans-unit.source: The primary way to debug and troubleshoot your server scripts is by writing to the service log.
trans-unit.target: The primary way to debug and troubleshoot your server scripts is by writing to the service log.

trans-unit.source: By default, Mobile Services writes errors that occur during service script execution to the service logs.
trans-unit.target: By default, Mobile Services writes errors that occur during service script execution to the service logs.

trans-unit.source: Your scripts can also write to the logs.
trans-unit.target: Your scripts can also write to the logs.

trans-unit.source: Writing to logs is great way to debug your scripts and validate that they are behaving as desired.
trans-unit.target: Writing to logs is great way to debug your scripts and validate that they are behaving as desired.

trans-unit.source: To write to the logs, use the global [console object].
trans-unit.target: To write to the logs, use the global [console object].

trans-unit.source: Use the log or info function to log information-level warnings.
trans-unit.target: Use the log or info function to log information-level warnings.

trans-unit.source: The warning and error functions log their respective levels, which are called-out in the logs.
trans-unit.target: The warning and error functions log their respective levels, which are called-out in the logs.

trans-unit.source: To view the logs for your mobile service, log on to the Management Portal, select your mobile service, and then choose the Logs tab.
trans-unit.target: To view the logs for your mobile service, log on to the Management Portal, select your mobile service, and then choose the Logs tab.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the logging functions of the [console object] to format your messages using parameters.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the logging functions of the [console object] to format your messages using parameters.
